IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: The mission of Jewish Community Foundation is to be the central source for long-term philanthropy, endowment and planned giving for individuals and institutions in our Colorado Jewish community.
IRS990.MissionDescription: The mission of the Jewish Community Foundation of Colorado is to be the central source for long-term philanthropy, endowment and planned giving for individuals and institutions in our Colorado Jewish community.
IRS990.Description: Jewish Community Foundation of Colorado is the planned-giving and endowment arm of the Allied Jewish Federation of Colorado Enterprise. For the Jewish Community Foundation (JCF), ensuring a vibrant Jewish future is part of our work every day. JCF works with individuals, families, and Jewish agencies and synagogues in an effort to build a foundation from which the next generation will prosper. JCF is committed to enabling our partners and donors to reach their goals and providing value added services that strengthen organizations and provide individuals with the tools to be impactful philanthropists during their lifetime and beyond. Furthermore, JCF is the only foundation in Colorado focused exclusively on the needs of the Jewish community, we are experts in Jewish philanthropy, and we provide access to a thoughtful, robust, and flexible investment platform. JCF manages 195 individual fund including trusts, restricted endowments, donor advised funds, supporting organizations, and charitable gift annuities. JCF also provides a prudent investment platform for local Jewish non-profit organizations and currently has 12 custodial accounts under management. JCF is working to strengthen financial resource development and community planning, and JCF provides individuals and institutions an option for long-term philanthropy, endowment and planned giving in Colorado's Jewish community.

OtherLiabilities.Description: FUNDS HELD ON BEHALF OF OTHERS

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Foundation adopted accounting guidance for uncertainty in income taxes on July 1, 2009. After evaluating the tax positions taken, none are considered to be uncertain; therefore, no amounts have been recognized as of June 30, 2010 and 2009. If incurred, interest and penalties associated with tax positions are recorded in the period assessed in management and general expenses. No interest or penalties have been assessed as of June 30, 2010 and 2009. Tax years that remain subject to examination include 2007 through the current year for the federal return and 2006 through the current year for the Colorado return. During the year ended June 30, 2010, the Foundation was notified of an Internal Revenue Service examination for the year ended June 30, 2007. The examination began in April 2010 and has not been completed as of the date of the auditors' report. Management does not believe there will be any changes to the return filed for the year ended June 30, 2007 based upon this examination. Because the outcome of this examination is uncertain, no amounts have been accrued as of June 30, 2010.

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Identifier: Procedures for Monitoring Use of Grants
Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Jewish Community Foundation requires an application process in which other organizations apply for funds. The application requires that a report be sent back to Jewish Community Foundation describing how the funds were used for their intended purpose.

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: Brad Friedman left his position at the Jewish Community Foundation on April 16, 2010. He received severance payments totaling $30,625 after his departure.

GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The organization monitors compliance of the conflict of interest policy by inquiring whether any new conflicts have arisen at each board meeting.

The organization does not have any paid employees, so it does not have a process for determining compensation. Top management and financial officers are shared with Allied Jewish Federation of Colorado (EIN 84-0402662), which is a related organization to Jewish Community Foundation. Allied Jewish Federation has a compensation committee in place that uses comparative data and maintains appropriate documentation to determine the compensation for all employees. The Board of Directors reviews the process.

The organization does not make its governing documents and conflict of interest policy available to the general public. The financial statements are made available on their website at www.jewishcolorado.org.

The return is first reviewed in detail by the Director of Finance. The return is then presented to the CEO and to the Financial Oversight Group. Upon their approval of the return, it is then provided to the board of directors prior to filing.

The organization does not have its own employees. The employees are shared with Allied Jewish Federation of Colorado (EIN: 84-0402662), which is a related organization to Jewish Community Foundation. Allied Jewish Federation has entered into a client services agreement with ADP TotalSource, Inc., which is a Professional Employer Organization (PEO). Employees of Allied Jewish Federation are considered employees of both Allied Jewish Federation and TotalSource. Allied Jewish Federation directs the employees in their day-to-day duties and activities, and it retains the right to control the means and manner of each employee's performance. The PEO arrangement enables Allied Jewish Federation to cost-effectively outsource certain human resource matters, employee benefits, and payroll and workers' compensation functions. Although TotalSource's name appears on the paychecks and W-2 Forms, the funds that provide the basis for the compensation is provided to TotalSource by Allied Jewish Federation.

There was a change in the executive director position during the year. Brad Friedman served as the executive director through April 16, 2010. Dirk Bird served as the executive director subsequent to that date through the end of the fiscal year. Because Dirk Bird did not begin in his role as executive director until April 2010, he did not have any compensation reported on Form W-2 or have any employer-provided benefits for the calendar year 2009.
